Name: Air moisture
Description: Water present in air in a gaseous form. Air moisture plays a significant role in weather when it changes from one state to another. These changes include condensation (cloud, fog, dew, and frost) and precipitation (rainfall and snowfall).

Name: Ambient Air
Description: refers to any unconfined portion of the atmosphere or outdoor air. basically the natural state of air in the outdoor environment

Name: Artificial
Description: Any substance that is not part of an aquatic environment and cannot be described by the activity medium codes.

Name: Borehole cuttings
Description: Unconsolidated material removed from a pipe or casing during a drilling (coring) operation

Name: Borrow Soil, Waste Rock, and Protore material
Description: material (usually soil, gravel or sand) has been dug for use at another location.soil or Rock may contain sub-economic material from which economic mineral deposits may form by geologic concentration processes such as supergene enrichment.

Name: Bottom material
Description: A mixture of mineral and organic matter that compose the top bed deposits (usually the first few inches) underlying a body of water. Bottom material consists of living and non-living, organic and inorganic material of varying physical, chemical, and biological composition that has been transported by water, ice, and wind and deposited in aquatic systems.

Name: Bulk Deposition
Description: the sum of. wet-only deposition and of sedimenting (dry) particles to. a sample collector in ambient air. The fluent delivery of a stream of separate loose pieces onto a receiving surface. The relative size of the pieces is not significant, rather it is the manner in which they are handled, as a mass or stream rather than each particle being individually manipulated.

Name: Canopy water
Description: Water dripping off tree-leaf canopies or running down the trunks of trees.

Name: Const. Material
Description: any material which is used for construction purposes. Many naturally occurring substances, such as clay, rocks, sand, and wood, even twigs and leaves, have been used to construct buildings

Name: Core material
Description: Consolidated or unconsolidated material removed from a pipe or casing during a drilling (coring) operation.

Name: Deionized Water
Description: Water that has had almost all of its mineral ions removed, such as cations like sodium, calcium, iron, and copper, and anions such as chloride and sulfate.

Name: Domestic Sewage
Description: Domestic sewage means sewage that consists of water and human excretions or other waterborne wastes incidental to the occupancy of a residential building. Domestic sewage carries used water from houses and apartments. it is also called sanitary sewage.

Name: Drinking Water
Description: known as potable water or improved drinking water, is water that is safe to drink or to use for food preparation, without risk of health problems.

Name: Dry Fall Material
Description: material formulated so that when applied at specified conditions, their droplets or overspray rapidly dry into a dust-like state before reaching a certain distance

Name: Effluent
Description: Treated or untreated wastewater after use at a facility or wastewater treatment plant, or from combined sources, such as combined-sewer overflows or tile drainage systems.

Name: Elutriate
Description: A process by which a mixture of an unconsolidated solid medium (usually soil) and a liquid medium (usually water) has been agitated for a given period of time to dissolve materials from the solid. The solid/liquid mixture is finally separated and the resulting solution is analyzed for materials dissolved during the elutriation process. separate (lighter and heavier particles in a mixture) by suspension in an upward flow of liquid or gas. purify by straining.

Name: Fecal material
Description: An unconsolidated material made up of warm-blooded animal or human wastes covering the ground, streambed, or suspended in a water body. Includes wastes from animal husbandry operations transferred to storage lagoons, or a slurry runoff. Fecal solids have generally not been processed and are sampled in their natural state.

Name: Filter Residue
Description: the solid mass remaining on a filter after the liquid that contained it has passed through. specifically the residue of impurities filtered from clarified juice of sugarcane that is used as a fertilizer

Name: Finished Water
Description: water that is introduced into the distribution system of a public water system and is intended for distribution and consumption without further treatment

Name: First flush
Description: First flush is the initial surface runoff of a rainstorm. During this phase, water pollution entering storm drains in areas with high proportions of impervious surfaces is typically more concentrated compared to the remainder of the storm. Monitors collect water samples from storm drains during the first major rainstorm of the winter season.. First Flush - The harvest period is late winter or early spring.

Name: Foam
Description: a mass of small bubbles formed on or in liquid, typically by agitation or fermentation.

Name: Geologic gases
Description: Gases originating from a geologic formation or series of formations which may include gases introduced through development or gases dissociated from an aqueous fraction prior to sample collection. These include fuel-related gases such as shale gas, tight-sand gas, coal gas, crude-oil gas, non-associated gas as well as non-fuel related ambient gases.

Name: Groundwater
Description: Water below the surface of the Earth contained in the saturated zone. It does not include soil moisture or interstitial water. Water that collects or flows beneath the Earth's surface, filling the porous spaces in soil, sediment, and rocks.

Name: Hyporheic zone
Description: Near-stream subsurface environment where mixing occurs between subsurface water and surface water. Water flows not only in the open stream channel, but also through the interstices of stream-channel and bank sediments, thus creating a mixing zone with subsurface water. There is not a precise separation between groundwater and surface water, thus the hyporheic zone is not precisely defined.

Name: Indoor Air
Description: refers to the air quality within and around buildings and structures, especially as it relates to the health and comfort of building occupants.

Name: Industrial Effluent
Description: Liquid waste flowing out of a factory, farm, commercial establishment

Name: Industrial Waste
Description: waste produced by industrial activity which includes any material that is rendered useless during a manufacturing process such as that of factories, industries, mills, and mining operations

Name: Interstitial Water
Description: (pore water), subterranean water in the pores of rocks, soils, and bottom sediments of oceans, seas, and lakes.

Name: Lake Sediment
Description: the accumulation of sand and dirt that settles in the bottom of lakes.

Name: Landfill effluent
Description: A liquid material (usually water) that is drained or pumped from a landfill. It usually is a liquid that has percolated through solid landfill material to become a transport medium for materials dissolved from the landfill.

Name: Leachate
Description: A solution obtained by passing a liquid (usually aqueous) through an unconsolidated solid medium, thereby dissolving materials (from the solid medium) which become a part of the solution. It also contains those precipitates that are the result of the solution process and subsequent chemical or biological reactions. any liquid that, in the course of passing through matter. the liquid that drains or 'leaches' from a landfill.

Name: Manure, green
Description: In agriculture, green manure is created by leaving uprooted or sown crop parts to wither on a field so that they serve as a mulch and soil amendment.[1] The plants used for green manure are often cover crops grown primarily for this purpose. Typically, they are ploughed under and incorporated into the soil while green or shortly after flowering.

Name: Manure, liquid
Description: Liquid manure is manure in a liquid form. Manure is changed into a liquid form by mixing the manure with water.

Name: Manure, solid
Description: Manure is organic matter, mostly derived from animal feces except in the case of green manure, which can be used as organic fertilizer in agriculture. Manures contribute to the fertility of the soil by adding organic matter and nutrients, such as nitrogen, that are utilised by bacteria, fungi and other organisms in the soil.

Name: Mine Tailings Pond
Description: Tailing ponds are areas of refused mining tailings where the waterborne refuse material is pumped into a pond to allow the sedimentation (meaning separation) of solids from the water. The pond is generally impounded with a dam, and known as tailings impoundments or tailings dams.

Name: Mixing Zone
Description: A mixing zone is an area of a lake or river where pollutants from a point source discharge are mixed, usually by natural means, with cleaner water. In the mixing zone, the level of toxic pollutants is allowed to be higher than the acceptable concentration for the general water body.

Name: Mixing Zone, Zone of Initial Dilution
Description: A zone of initial dilution or ZID is defined as a small area in the immediate vicinity of an outfall structure in which turbulence from the eflhtent velocity is high and causes rapid mixing with the surrounding water. Turbulence for rapid mixing can be provided in three ways. The most common way is with the use of an effluent diffuser. This method assures adequate velocities and mixing if it is properly designed for the discharge area.

Name: Municipal Sewage Effluent
Description: Sewage treatment is the process of removing contaminants from wastewater, primarily from household sewage. It includes physical, chemical, and biological processes to remove these contaminants and produce environmentally safer treated wastewater (or treated effluent).

Name: Municipal Waste
Description: waste from households, and other waste that, because of its nature or composition, is similar to waste from households.

Name: Ocean Water
Description: Seawater, or salt water, is water from a sea or ocean. On average, seawater in the world's oceans has a salinity of about 3.5% (35 g/L, 599 mM)

Name: Oil/Oily Sludge
Description: Any sludge and/or float generated from the physical and/or chemical separation of oil/water/solids in process wastewaters and oily cooling wastewaters from petroleum refineries.

Name: Plant water
Description: Water that is extracted from plant tissue and subsequently analyzed for its chemical properties. This includes both intra- and extracellular water in the plant tissue.

Name: Pore water
Description: water contained in pores in soil or rock. Water beneath the earth's surface, often between saturated soil and rock, that supplies wells and springs.

Name: Produced water
Description: Water that is a byproduct of oil and gas development. Produced water is associated with the oil and gas reservoir and may include formation waters and (or) injected fluids and solids introduced during resource development.

Name: Rainwater
Description: water that has fallen as or been obtained from rain.

Name: Rock/Cobbles/Gravel
Description: Particle size, also called grain size, refers to the diameter of individual grains of sediment, or the lithified particles in clastic rocks. ... Granular material can range from very small colloidal particles, through clay, silt, sand, gravel, and cobbles, to boulders.

Name: Septic Effluent
Description: collect sewage from residences and businesses, and the effluent that comes out of the tank is sent to either a centralized sewage treatment plant or a distributed treatment system

Name: Sieved Sediment
Description: characterizing the particle size distribution of a sediment sample thru a device for separating wanted elements from unwanted material

Name: Sludge
Description: thick, soft, wet mud or a similar viscous mixture of liquid and solid components, especially the product of an industrial or refining process

Name: Snowmelt
Description: the melting of fallen snow

Name: Soil Gas
Description: the gases found in the air space between soil components. The primary natural soil gases include nitrogen, carbon dioxide and oxygen. The oxygen is critical because it allows for respiration of both plant roots and soil organisms. Other natural soil gases are atmospheric methane and radon.

Name: Soil moisture
Description: Water occupying voids between loose soil particles within the aerated root zone. The water is held in place by surface tension, capillary and hydroscopic forces in opposition to the pull of gravitational forces.

Name: Solids
Description: Unconsolidated materials that may be soils, cores, borehole cuttings, sediments, matter suspended in water or wastewater, street sweepings, other particulate matter, or the total array of materials that are collected as part of a "clean sweep"

Name: Stack Gases
Description: combustion product gases called flue gases are exhausted to the outside air.

Name: Stormwater
Description: surface water in abnormal quantity resulting from heavy falls of rain or snow.

Name: Subsurface Soil/Sediment
Description: relating to, or situated in an area beneath a surface, especially the surface of the earth or of a body of wate, soil or sediment

Name: Surface Soil/Sediment
Description: relating to or occurring on the upper or outer part of something.soil or sediment

Name: Surface Water
Description: Water on the surface of the Earth stored or transported in rivers, streams, estuaries, lakes, ponds, swamps, glaciers, or other aquatic areas. It also may refer to water in urban drains and storm-sewer systems. water that collects on the surface of the ground. water on the surface of the planet such as in a river, lake, wetland, or ocean.

Name: Surface Water Sediment
Description: Sediments are most often transported by water (fluvial processes), but also wind (aeolian processes) and glaciers. Beach sands and river channel deposits are examples of fluvial transport and deposition, though sediment also often settles out of slow-moving or standing water in lakes and oceans.

Name: Suspended sediment
Description: Sediment carried in suspension by the turbulent components of the fluid or by Brownian motion

Name: Treated water supply
Description: Water after being processed for some particular use(s)

Name: USGS Standard Reference Sample
Description: Samples provided by the USGS for quality assurance testing

Name: UnSieved Sediment
Description: preserved characterized particle size distribution of a sediment sample

Name: Unknown
Description: Unknown

Name: Untreated water supply
Description: Untreated water supply from a blend of surface and ground waters or from unknown sources.

Name: Waste Gas
Description: Waste Gas is meant to represent landfill gas. Waste gas means a natural gas that contains a greater percentage of gaseous chemical impurities than the percentage of methane. For purposes of this definition, gaseous chemical impurities may include carbon dioxide, nitrogen, helium, or hydrogen sulfide.

Name: Wastewater Treatment Plant Effluent
Description: the final product of all earlier treatment processes, and it can be discharged to a stream, river, bay, lagoon or wetland. Sometimes effluent

Name: Wastewater Treatment Plant Influent
Description: Influent is water, waste water or other liquid flowing into a reservoir, basin or treatment plant.

Name: Water-Vadose Zone
Description: The vadose zone, also termed the unsaturated zone, is the part of Earth between the land surface and the top of the phreatic zone, the position at which the groundwater (the water in the soil's pores) is at atmospheric pressure ("vadose" is from the Latin for "shallow")

Name: Wet Fall Material
Description: material formulated so that when applied at specified conditions, formings a droplets-like state before reaching a certain distance

Name: Wipe
Description: a disposable cloth for wiping things clean
